The prolonged state of conflict in Afghanistan has resulted in 
large-scale deterioration of the civil aviation infrastructure and 
a  depletion  of  skilled  personnel.  In  addition  to  the  lack  of 
maintenance, the deterioration was further accelerated by the 
heavy  damage  inflicted  by  prolonged  civil  strife  and  military 
operations. Afghanistan relies significantly on the civil aviation 
sector  for  keeping  most  of  its  remote  communities  within 
reach  of  much  needed  humanitarian  aid  and  basic  public 
services.  Rehabilitating  and  strengthening  the  civil  aviation 
sector is crucial for extending the reach of the Government in 
Kabul,  thereby  facilitating  stabilization  and  integration  of  the 
country.  Rehabilitation  of  the  civil  aviation  infrastructure  is  a 
prerequisite  for  private  sector  service  providers  to  provide 
efficient  and  affordable  means  of  transport  to  most  of  the 
population  living  in  remote  rural  provinces.  The  rehabilitation 
of  the  airports  will  also  help  create  employment,  generate 
income  at  the  household  level,  improve  safety,  improve  the 
spread  of  medical  facilities,  help  reconcile  different  ethnic 
groups,  and  unify  the  country  politically.  To  the  extent 
possible,  the  Project  will  use  labor-intensive  construction 
methods  to  provide  badly  needed  employment  and  income 
generation  opportunities.  It  will  contribute  to  social  stability 
and  poverty  reduction  by  engaging  those  internally  displaced 
because of the war and civil unrest. Thus this investment will 
contribute significantly to improving the overall socioeconomic 
situation and mitigating the pervasive poverty.

Afghanistan  is  a  landlocked  country.  Its  population,  estimated  at  26  million,  is  spread 
over  some  652,000  square  kilometers  of  mostly  mountainous  terrain.  Apart  from  Kabul,  the 
capital, and a few provincial capitals such as Herat, Kandahar, and Mazar-e-Sharif, Afghanistan 
has few population centers. With the rugged Hindu Kush mountains occupying the geographical 
center of the country, the population centers are physically separated by steep mountains or by 
desert.  In  the  absence  of  a  railway  system  and  functioning  river  ports,  Afghanistan  depends 
solely on road and air transport for the movement of passengers and goods. Since the end of 
the  conflict,  the  country  has  made  massive  efforts  to  rehabilitate  its  3,300-kilometer  primary 
road network, which consists of a ring road that connects Kabul to major population centers and 
international  links  to  neighboring  countries.  While  the  road  network  will  offer  reliable  links 
capable  of  transporting  large  volumes  of  goods  and  people  when  rehabilitation  has  been 
completed,  air  transport  will  continue  to  offer  the  best,  and  often  the  only,  quick  link  between 
remote  provinces  and  Kabul.  Because  of  its  strategic  geographic  location,  Afghanistan’s 
airspace offers one of the shortest routes between Asia and Europe, thus keeping Afghanistan’s 
airspace open to international overflights broadly benefits both the international community and 
the country. 
 
Afghanistan  has  two  major  air  gateways:  Kabul  International  Airport  serving  the  capital

more  remote  areas.  These  airports  have  mainly  graveled  airside  facilities  and  operate  under

2. 

Sector Management 

 
5. 
The  Ministry  of  Civil  Aviation  and  Tourism  (MCAT)  is  responsible  for  operating  and 
maintaining  the  country’s  22  airports.  MCAT  also  owns  the  national  airline  (Ariana  Afghan 
Airlines)  and  major  hotels  and  is  responsible  for  promoting  tourism  and  providing  related 
services. MCAT is divided into eight presidencies, and currently has about 1,200 staff. Because 
of the deteriorated infrastructure and the depletion of trained staff, MCAT is unable to provide 
adequate  air  traffic  control  for  Afghanistan’s  airspace.  Given  existing  controllers;  technical 
support staff; and communications, surveillance, and navigation systems, assuring the safety of 
flights  over  Afghanistan  is  impossible.  Immediate  action  has  to  be  taken  to  rehabilitate  and 
improve MCAT’s institutional capacity to operate and maintain the country’s airports. 
 
6. 
The  Ministry  of  Public  Works  was  responsible  for  airport  design,  construction,  and 
maintenance. While MCAT currently continues to be responsible for airport management at all 
airports and air traffic control at certain large domestic airports, the role of the Ministry of Public 
Works has been defunct for many years. As a result, little airport maintenance work has been 
carried  out  since  1989.  MCAT  currently  has  no  capability  for  carrying  out  either  day-to-day  or 
major periodic airport maintenance, but intends to take over the airport design, construction, and 
maintenance role in the future. 
 
7. 
MCAT carries out regulatory functions on the basis of the Civil Aviation Act of July 2003. 
However,  the  act  is  seriously  deficient  in  that  it  does  not  provide  MCAT  with  the  powers  and 
authority to regulate civil aviation, such as the authority to issue the kinds of regulations, orders, 
and  directives  necessary  to  ensure  the  safety  of  aviation.  The  reestablishment  of  a  regulatory 
system  and  of  the  capability  to  oversee  safety  is  urgently  needed  to  ensure  the  safety  of  air 
operations and the commercial success of Ariana Afghan Airlines. In the future, the regulatory 
framework will be based on a new civil aviation act that will enable the establishment of a civil 
aviation authority to act as a regulator instead of MCAT

Air Transport Services 

 
8. 
Prior to 1989, air travel was a well-developed mode of transport in Afghanistan, popular 
with  tourists  and  Afghan  business  people,  Government  officials,  and  other  users  who  could 
afford  to  fly.  The  national  airline,  Ariana  Afghan  Airlines,  was  established  in  1955  and  has 
continued to operate, despite the adverse circumstances of the last two decades. At its peak in 
the  late  1970s,  Ariana’s  fleet  regularly  flew  to  major  Western  European  cities  as  well  as  to 
neighboring  countries.  During  the  last  decade,  however,  Ariana  lost  most  of  its  international 
routes  mainly  because  of  the  conflict  within  the  country  and  international  sanctions  imposed 
against the previous regime. It also lost most of its fleet and trained personnel.  
 
9. 
Since  the  end  of  the  conflict,  Ariana  has  been  expanding  its  international  reach.  It 
currently owns seven aircraft and operates international flights to 13 destinations to as far away 
as Germany. However, the old age of its fleet, the shortage of properly trained personnel, the 
poorly equipped maintenance facilities, and the lack of proper oversight functions in MCAT have 
contributed to concerns about the safety and reliability of Ariana’s fleet operations. In addition to 
Ariana, foreign airlines from nearby countries have started services to Afghanistan and Afghan 
airspace is rapidly opening up to international flights.

Security Situation 

 
28. 
Security  is  the  main  issue  and  constraint  in  relation  to  reconstruction.  Without  an 
adequate  level  of  security,  the  country  will  fail  to  achieve  key  national  goals  for  economic 
growth, political normalization and national reconciliation, and social development. Afghanistan 
has  made  significant  gains  in  security  in  the  last  2  years  that  have  laid  a  solid  foundation  for 
continued and accelerated reform and has avoided a resurgence of major civil conflict. Sporadic 
outbreaks  of  armed  conflict,  even  if  not  always  fully  resolved,  have  been  contained  and 
prevented  from  spreading.  The  internationally  sponsored  security  arrangements  for  Kabul, 
based  on  the  international  security  assistance  forces  working  in  cooperation  with  Afghan 
security  forces,  have  worked  reasonably  well.  Some  improvements  have  been  made  in  the 
police force, and the first units of a national army have been formed and trained. Security on the 
main intercity roads has improved significantly compared with the situation 2 years ago.  
 
29. 
Nevertheless, the security situation has deteriorated in parts of the country, particularly 
in  rural  areas.  Opium  poppy  cultivation,  which  had  been  sharply  reduced  during  2000,  and 
especially  in  2001,  made  a  strong  comeback  in  2002,  and  cultivation  expanded  further  during 
the 2003 season. Narcotics production and trade and the profits from these activities constitute 
a  major  threat  to  Afghanistan’s  security,  political  normalization,  and  economic  development. 
Containment  and  eradication  of  illicit  drug  production  will  inevitably  be  a  long-term  effort  that 
requires  a  combination  of  effective  law  enforcement  and  rural  development  that  generates 
alternative livelihoods. 
 
30. 
The disarmament, demobilization, and reintegration program to reduce the number and 
size  of  private  militias  and  undercut  the  military  strength  of  the  regional  governors  has 
progressed  slowly.  A  number  of  local  militias  have  resisted,  claiming  that  the  Ministry  of 
Defense was monopolized by a particular ethnic group. Even though the Government replaced 
a  number  of  senior  ministry  officials  belonging  to  this  ethnic  group  with  officials  belonging  to 
other ethnic groups in September 2003, some concerns linger about the loyalty of lower-ranking 
ministry officials. This situation enables regional warlords to maintain their military strength and 
continue to influence regional politics, which has not helped the security situation. The security 
situation will continue to constrain the progress of reconstruction, and concerns about security 
may continue to discourage foreign and large-scale domestic investment. 
 
31.

Opium-Related Problems 

 
32. 
Afghanistan is the world’s largest producer of illicit opium. The current ban on cultivation 
has  had  an  extremely  limited  effect,  and  opium  is  a  major  source  of  cash  income  for  farmers 
because of its ready profitability and because of a lack of other livelihood alternatives. According 
to  the  United  Nations  Office  on  Drugs  and  Crime  (UNODC),  opium  was  cultivated  on  80,000 
hectares  in 2003, an increase of 8% over 2002, and production increased by 6% to 3,968 tons, 
20  times  more  than  in  2001,  the  last  year  of  Taliban  rule.  Farmers  grew  poppies  in  28  of  the 
country’s 32 provinces in 2003, up from 18 in 1999. UNODC estimates that 264,000 families, or 
about 7% of Afghanistan’s population, are producing poppies, each cultivating an average of 0.3 
hectares.  UNODC  estimates  average  yearly  earnings  at  $3,900  per  opium-growing  family,  or 
$594 per capita, in a country where per capita gross domestic product is only $207. The share 
of poppy production in the economy is large. If opium exports were included, total exports would 
be 40% greater.  
 
33. 
Poppy  cultivation  and  narcotics  production  and  trade  constitute  a  major  threat  to 
Afghanistan’s  security  and  political  normalization  and  tie  a  poor  rural  population  to  regional 
warlords  and  international  crime  syndicates.  To  combat  this  problem,  the  Government  has 
developed a national counternarcotics strategy and is working with aid agencies involved in the 
security  sector  on  containing  and  eradicating  poppy  cultivation  and  providing  support  for 
alternative  livelihoods.  ADB  support  focuses  on  helping  farm  households  develop  livelihood 
alternatives  to  poppy  cultivation.  ADB  activities  in  this  regard  include  creating  an  enabling 
environment  for  the  commercialization  and  diversification  of  agricultural  production  and 
rehabilitating irrigation systems, which ADB is pursuing through a demand-driven, participatory, 
and  community-based  approach.  ADB  is  also  supporting  measures  to  contain  the  flow  of 
narcotics  across  borders  through  some  of  its  subregional activities, including  building  capacity 
and strengthening customs and immigration departments in the region.

34. 
A  number  of  lessons  can  be  drawn  from  past  emergency  assistance  projects,  best 
practices, and ADB’s initial lending and nonlending operations in Afghanistan since 2002. First, 
continued emphasis has to be given to capacity building to improve planning, project design and 
implementation, administration, and financial management. Second, aid coordination by means 
of consultative groups is important for avoiding duplication and delays. Third, aid groups must 
work closely with a country’s MOF and central bank to develop a viable and working payment 
system,  without  which  maintaining  a  flow  of  funds  is  difficult.  Fourth,  capacity  building  in 
executing  agencies  is  vital,  and  consulting  services  for  project  design  and  implementation 
should provide for the training of executing agency staff in the operations and maintenance of 
rehabilitated  facilities.  Fifth,  the  number  of  procurement  packages  should  be  minimized,  given 
the limited implementation capacity of executing agencies. Sixth, ADB’s procurement guidelines 
should  be  applied  flexibly  for  emergency  assistance  projects  to  allow  reduced  procurement 
periods  for  the  urgent  delivery  of  project  components.  Seventh,  law  and  order  situations 
resulting  from  conflict  hamper  the  smooth  implementation  of  projects  and  extensive  security 
plans should be put in place to address possible security hazards in project locations. All these 
lessons have been incorporated into the design of the Project.

The benefits to operators are substantial in terms of improvements in aircraft productivity

tires. Aircraft landing on a gravel surface take longer to stop than on a bitumen surface because

also  severely  diminish  the  risk  and  economic  costs  of  accidents  or  other  incidents  caused  by

Civil  aviation  has  always  played  an  important  role  in  transportation  in  Afghanistan

2. 
Prior to 1989, civil aviation was reasonably well developed and well patronized by local

125,000 passengers traveled between 12 airports. However, after 20 years of conflict, most of

wait  many  years  for  good  road  connections.  Many  roads  may  never  be  upgraded  to  highway 
standards because of constraints imposed by the terrain.

market-oriented industry with a more commercial outlook.

Poverty Analysis  

                                                                                                      Poverty Intervention 

B. 
Phase I of the project will cover seven regional airports in the provinces of Badakhshan, Bagdis, Bamyan, Farah, Faryab, 
Ghor, and Nimroz with a total population of about 3,201,000. Of the seven airports, Maimana is the major economic center 
and  has  the  largest  population,  while  Qalai-Naw  has  the  lowest.  Nationally,  approximately  53%  of  the  population  is 
classified as poor and living on less than $1 per day or approximately 2,100 kilocalories per day. In the project provinces, 
the  average  daily  income  is  less  than  $1,  no  more  than  $0.74  per  person  per  day,  compared  with  the  national  average 
income  of  an  unskilled  laborer  of  $1.7  to  $3.2  per  day.  The  prolonged  war,  further  exasperated  by  drought,  has  severely 
affected people’s livelihoods. The decline in farm productivity and the loss of seasonal opportunities for agricultural labor is 
one of the main determinants of poverty, because unskilled labor is often piecemeal over time or seasonal as opposed to a 
regular income source over the year. The social assessment in the project area also revealed that 50% to 60% of residents 
lived below the poverty line and had an average income of AF2,000 to AF3,000  per month. Thus poverty levels are high in 
the project provinces.  
 
Demographic health indicators of poverty reveal that Afghanistan ranks fourth highest in the mortality rate for children under 
5  at  257  deaths  per  1,000  and  has  a  high  infant  mortality  rate  of  165  per  1,000.1  In the  phase  1  provinces,  the  maternal 
mortality rate is an extremely high 820 per 100,000 live births, and average life expectancy is just 44 years, compared to 60 
to  75  years  in  neighboring  countries.  Access  to  reproductive  health  services  for  mothers  is  extremely  limited.  More  than 
70%  of  deliveries  are  at  home.  Basic  health  center  facilities  are  generally  more  concentrated  in  Badakhshan  than  in  the 
other provinces. The facilities within the basic health centers are extremely poor because of the prolonged disturbances and 
the  out-migration  of  medical  personnel.  In  addition,  nearly  99%  of  the  households  in  the  project  provinces  lack  sanitary 
facilities,  most  resort  to  unsafe  sources  of  water,  and  adult  literacy  ranges  from  15%  among  the  male  population  to  less 
than 7% among the female population. 
 
The project would have both direct and indirect poverty reduction impacts. The direct poverty impact would be on income 
generation and the demand for unskilled labor. The direct benefit to poor households will be employment in construction of 
airstrip perimeter fences, terminal buildings, and other passenger facilities in terms of net income earned during the period 
of the project. Expectations are that this additional income will be spent within families on education, nutrition, agricultural 
implements,  seed,  and  fertilizer,  which  will  benefit  families  and  communities  through  surplus  crops  and  improve  their 
income levels. The Project will generate 380 person-months of employment opportunities for unskilled labor. Both poor and 
non-poor households are likely to benefit directly in the medium and long term, as additional jobs will be created in airport 
administration  and  management  and  in  the  tourist  industry.  Employment  opportunities  will  also  be  created  in  fire  fighting 
services,  catering,  private  airline  services,  and  car  hire  services  for  business  travelers  and  tourists  and  within  small  and 
large contractor firms that will be responsible for the operations and maintenance of the airports in the future.

Minor  and  short-term  environmental  impacts  are  anticipated  during  the  construction
